bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, July 7, 1915

div1.p: Carter describes life in the camp, field work, and financial matters.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, July 7, 1915
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE.
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
??? ??? Ala
July 7/15
My Dear Laura:
div1.p:
It seems a long time since I wrote
to you & yet I think. I wrote a postal last
Saturday or Sunday. Which was it?

This is the “Jumping Off Place”! It
is a mining town-or rather Camp-
About the head of navigation of the
left (eastern) fork of the Black War-
rior.- We reached it Sunday a-
bout 1 A.M. in a launch- We
walked - 1 1/2 miles, & found a boar-
ding house - the only one we could
hear of. We, that itis LePrince & Dr Grif-
fitts, pushed a hand - car - from the
2
Camp to the boat (1 1/2 miles) got
the trunks & came up 1/2 mile &
met a Wagon, which brought them
here, We slept - 5 in a room - the
first night. 2 R. R. men & we three
but since then have a room to
us 3. The regular charge is
75 cents per day for board- (or
$5.00 per week) but we agree to pay 10 cents
10 cents extra because it our coming
will require the hiring of an extra help
30 cents per day.

The place is clean & the buscuit are
do cooked done, & the water is good
so it is all right for a temporary
stay, I really don't care how tempora-
ry
is
3
temporary however. I really get
all I want to eat & it is good enough
- we have had chicken once. It is
cool, quite cool at night. That & good
water make up for many minor
discomforts- Also I have felt no
red-bugs since last Saturday -
this is Wednesday. We have seen
no ice since Saturday a week ago
at Tuscaloosa.

W There have been terrific rains in
this section - about 5 maybe 6 inches
of water fell- July 2d, 3d & 4th; which
has a & the river is about 6 feet
above normal. This has interfered with our work very
much, lost us all of two days I
think. Indeed I did not take the
party
4
out today as it would have been
useless. What we did yester-
day & Monday was of little value. Still it
gives us a chance to examine a
swollen river & every new
view point contains some in-
formation. At any rate resting
today gives me a chance to write
this letter. LePrince & Griffitts
have walked across the country
- about 4 miles - to see if we can
make arrangements to board
2 or 3 days with some farmers
so that we can be close to our base
in in examining a certain creek
(Prescott's) which we want to look
into
5
into. We are not going to
leave this place however un-
til we get our mail, I especi-
ally want to get June's check
& start it back to Baltimore.

I have become hard & tough. Am
careful about going up hills &
do not begin to do the work I
did last year, yet I do as
much or more than the aver-
age man of my age can do,
& am not hurt by it. Eat
enough, I am very careful a-
bout eating, & think that I will
get rid of all superfluous fat
on this trip. Walk a plenty,
paddle a canoe, an hour or so
- say 3 to 4 hours
6
per day - & am not unduly tired
when night comes.

But for the rain we would
have gone to Cordova-, head
of Navigation of the West fork -
on Saturday, but as it has
happened I cannot tell what
we will do. We may not go
there at all as I am anx-
ious to get into South Carolina
- Parr Shoals, When we must do
so I may learn by the next mail
- tomorrow night I think - from Dr
Hayne,- A week between mails is
a reminder of Chandeleur. Cordova
is a town - 1500 to 2000 people I hear &
I judge more civilized than
this
7
this. However this is more a-
musing than annoying - as long
as the weather is reasonably coal
cool & one keeps well. It can't
stay cool much longer however
& so I hope we will soon get away.

We are going to await our mail
here - for - even on Prescott's
creek - on we will get our
mail here, because we
are getting short of money.
I have been financing
the whole party to some extent.
I have 2 $ 23.00/100 left & am keeping
enough to get to Birmingham
the at all hazards. If the necessary
then I will
8
go over it is 36 miles only - &
borrow from Noland or - rather
get him to cash a check, not
not to be put in for collec-
tion until - say - July 20,
so as to get my U.S. check in
first.

I am due $140, from the Yadkin
valley Power Company, which ought to be
in the mail by Saturday & $45,
may's accounts from the Bureau, LePrince
is due about $110 from the first
& $90 from the Bureau, I have
an account of $116 00/100 for June - which
I can't send in until I get a receipt
for $33 00/100. I sent (check for) to the Ala Pow-
er Company,
this so you see I will have money enough
when I get it. This is a long letter
my dear & I hope you will enjoy
getting it
